name: AI Transformation World
description: Artificial intelligence achieves breakthrough capabilities that fundamentally transform the global economy and society. AI drives unprecedented productivity gains across sectors while creating new industries and reshaping labor markets. However, the benefits are unevenly distributed, potentially concentrating wealth among AI platform owners while displacing traditional workers.
key_drivers: AI breakthroughs enable 40-60% productivity gains by 2035
AGI or highly capable AI systems achieve widespread deployment
AI excels at many cognitive and manual tasks but distribution of gains varies
Regulatory and policy responses determine whether benefits are shared or concentrated

name: Climate Crisis World
description: Accelerating climate change becomes the dominant global challenge, triggering massive economic restructuring, infrastructure investment, and social upheaval. Extreme weather events overwhelm adaptation efforts while forcing fundamental changes to how societies organize economically and politically. Climate impacts drive migration, conflict, and systemic disruption across all sectors.
key_drivers: Climate impacts accelerate beyond current projections with tipping point cascades
Extreme weather events become more frequent and severe globally
Climate adaptation requires trillions in infrastructure spending
Climate migration reaches 200+ million people by 2040
Emergency powers become normalized as governments respond to repeated crises

name: Fragmented World Order
description: The post-Cold War global order breaks down into competing blocs and spheres of influence. US-China rivalry intensifies while other powers assert independence, leading to economic decoupling, reduced international cooperation, and increased military tensions. Global governance becomes fragmented across issue-specific coalitions rather than unified institutions.
key_drivers: US-China strategic competition escalates with extensive decoupling
International trade and cooperation decline due to nationalism and security concerns
Military buildups and proxy conflicts increase globally
Alternative payment systems and alliance networks emerge
Multilateral institutions weaken as great powers compete

name: Great Demographic Transition
description: Global population dynamics undergo dramatic shifts as fertility rates decline rapidly in developing countries while longevity increases. This creates massive changes in working-age populations, economic growth patterns, and social structures. Migration flows redistribute populations while aging societies struggle with labor shortages and fiscal pressures.
key_drivers: Global fertility rates decline faster than expected across developing nations
Life expectancy gains slow while healthy lifespan potentially extends significantly
Climate and economic migration reaches unprecedented scales
Aging populations in developed countries create labor shortages
Social security and healthcare systems face mounting fiscal pressures

name: Innovation Plateau World
description: Technological progress slows significantly due to fundamental limitations, regulatory barriers, or economic constraints. AI development hits technical barriers while other breakthrough technologies fail to materialize. Economic growth remains modest as productivity gains plateau and traditional industries maintain competitiveness against automation.
key_drivers: AI capabilities hit fundamental technical barriers or face regulatory restrictions
Energy costs, chip shortages, or economic shocks limit technology deployment
Public backlash leads to restrictive governance of emerging technologies
Investment in R&D declines due to diminishing returns or competing priorities
Traditional human-centered approaches remain competitive

name: Governance Revolution World
description: Political systems worldwide undergo fundamental transformation as traditional democracy faces challenges from authoritarianism while new forms of governance emerge. Digital natives reshape political institutions while climate change and inequality stress existing democratic frameworks. The outcome varies between democratic renewal, authoritarian consolidation, or hybrid governance models.
key_drivers: Generational transition brings digital natives to political power globally
Economic inequality and climate stress challenge democratic legitimacy
Surveillance technology capabilities favor different governance models
Youth demographics drive pro-democracy movements in some regions
New forms of participatory and decentralized governance emerge

name: Financial System Breakdown
description: The global financial system experiences severe stress from multiple sources including debt overhangs, climate risks, and systemic failures. Traditional insurance markets partially collapse while sovereign debt crises emerge. Despite safe-haven demand, fiscal sustainability concerns drive higher risk premiums and structural changes to capital markets.
key_drivers: Federal and corporate debt levels become unsustainable triggering crisis
Traditional insurance and reinsurance markets face widespread failures
Climate disasters and compound catastrophes overwhelm risk management
Interest payments consume increasing shares of government revenues
Credit remains constrained affecting economic growth and recovery

name: Biological Catastrophe World
description: A severe global pandemic emerges from natural evolution, laboratory accident, or deliberate release, causing millions of deaths and overwhelming healthcare systems. This could involve highly pathogenic influenza, engineered pathogens, antimicrobial-resistant bacteria, or climate-released diseases. The event reshapes global preparedness and international cooperation around biological threats.
key_drivers: Highly pathogenic pathogen emerges with both high transmissibility and mortality
Initial detection and response are delayed allowing widespread spread
Healthcare systems become overwhelmed leading to cascade effects
Vaccine development and deployment face significant technical or logistical barriers
International cooperation is hindered by attribution concerns or resource competition

name: Managed Stability World
description: Despite ongoing challenges and tensions, international institutions and crisis management mechanisms prove resilient enough to prevent major catastrophes. Gradual adaptation occurs across multiple domains while maintaining relative stability. Changes happen incrementally rather than through dramatic disruptions, with mixed outcomes across different regions and sectors.
key_drivers: Crisis management mechanisms and international cooperation prevent major escalations
Gradual adaptation and incremental change rather than revolutionary transformation
Mixed outcomes with some regions/sectors improving while others decline
Established institutions prove more resilient than anticipated
Status quo bias and conservative approaches dominate policy responses

name: Cascade Collapse World
description: Multiple interconnected crises create a systemic breakdown where individual challenges amplify each other beyond society's ability to respond effectively. Climate disasters trigger economic collapse, which enables conflict and political breakdown, which prevents coordinated responses to further challenges. Traditional institutions and international cooperation break down under the weight of compound crises.
key_drivers: Multiple overlapping crises create systemic amplification effects
Traditional institutions and governance systems prove inadequate for compound challenges
International cooperation breaks down amid nationalism and resource competition
Economic collapse and social instability become self-reinforcing
Emergency response and rebuilding capacity becomes overwhelmed
